Cedric Beust wrote:

> > From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> > Behalf Of Jason Rogers
>
> > One tack I take in doing these types of workshops is to
> > concentrate on unit testing skills, not language issues.  I
> > therefore tend to choose a language platform that is
> > unfamiliar to the wider audience.  This helps the audience to
> > not get caught up in implementation details (eg. coding
> > styles, method names, etc.) because if it is a language they
> > are unfamiliar with they will tend not to bother about those
> > things.
>
> ...  but it seems to me they will be even more distracted by having to 
> learn
> this unfamiliar platform and language.

That's just the point.  They didn't have to learn the 
platform/language.  We focused on concepts, not implementation.  The 
follow-up courses would need more knowledge of the platform/language.  
But with those follow-ups I still don't tend to force it upon them.  I 
let the audience choose what suits them from an array of platforms and 
languages.  We lay down ground rules for what the platform needs to be 
able to accomplish and they are off on their own while I facilitate 
discussion and problem-solving.  This type of environment (more often 
than not) also lends quite well to code sharing, paired programming, 
quick spikes, etc. which are very useful in the realm of testing.

>
> IMO, it should be the instructor who adjusts their class to what their
> students know and not the other way around...

In principal I don't disagree with you -- however, the students aren't 
expected to adjust what they know to my class.

In taking this approach, I was helping the students to get the baggage 
out of the way.  I do this type of class with seasoned programmers who 
don't have much experience in automated unit testing and it works 
beautifully.  That isn't just my opinion, all the feedback I get from 
these classes are generally very positive in regards to the language & 
platform I end up choosing.  As I said in my original post, your mileage 
may vary.  However, I think you do yourself a disservice by shooting it 
down without trying it or experiencing it.

--
